text: Antoine-François Brisson (25 October 1728, in Paris – 1796, in Lyon) was an 18th-century French lawyer. An inspector of commerce and manufacture for the financial district of Lyon, Brisson published Manière de retirer de la pomme de terre la poudre blanche que l'on nomme amidon, fécule farine, Lyon, 1779 and Mémoires historiques et économiques sur le Beaujolais, Lyon, 1795. Brisson was a member of various academies, including the which keeps twenty-three manuscripts from him on several topics, and the Académie de Villefranche. He wrote the articles toilerie and Suisses, privileges des Suisses en France pour leur commerce for the Encyclopédie by Diderot. His son, Barnabé Brisson (1777–1828), was an engineer. J.J. O'Connor; E.F. Robertson: Barnabé Brisson. School of Mathematics and Statistics. University of St Andrews, Scotland == Sources == * Joseph-Marie Quérard, La Littérature française contemporaine. XIXe, t. 1, Paris, Daguin Frères, 1842, p. 533\. == References == == External links == * Antoine-françois Brisson on Wikisource * Notice on Persée Category:18th-century French lawyers Category:Contributors to the Encyclopédie (1751–1772) Category:People from Paris Category:1728 births Category:1796 deaths
title: Antoine-François Brisson
